answerText: Photoelectric effect[10] In order to measure the energy of the ejected photoelectrons, a charged plate is be placed near the emitter. This is the point at which the work done by the repulsive force equals the energy of the electrons.
heading: Penn Bowl |2012 | Editors Packet 2 | 13 | Science | Physics | College
subject: Science
question: Question: When turned to a low intensity, the light involved in this phenomenon was observed to produce countable emissions which were directly proportional to the intensity of the light. For 10 points each: [10]  Name this effect explained by Albert Einstein in one of his Annus Mirabilis papers. It occurs when light with energy  above the work function of a metal knocks namesake particles off of a plate of that metal.
